body: Sorry, mis-pr'd ;)

It would also be useful do document the distinction between limitSpec and orderBy, since they both expressed in the same way.

Hi!

Thanks for the contrib! Before I can merge the pull request, we need you to
agree to our CLA. In the repo there is an individual CLA and a corporate
CLA. If you are working on your own behalf and agree to the CLA, responding
here with a comment of "I agree to the terms of the Druid Individual CLA as
it exists in the current master branch" is sufficient. If you are working on
behalf of a company, can you have your company fill out the corporate CLA
and submit it to us? Thanks again!

Hi,

I will take care of that tomorrow. I let you know when it's done.

In general this looks good to me.  A lot of equals and hashCode() were implemented and I didn't look too closely at them.  They look like they are auto-generated by the IDE, so I'm going to assume that they are correct (and if they aren't and the unit tests didn't catch it, then, well, we'll have a good chance to make better unit tests in the future).
Are there any tests for group by and concurrent group by?
yeah, we had a test for groupBy for wikipedia segments, I have recently added a groupBy test for twitter segments also that runs the query concurrently on 3 segments
I know there was some discussion over IRC over this. Was this resolved?

One other general comment I have is that I think we should also get the "query/wait" metric in the broker as part of this pull request

btw waittime was not being enabled for the metricsrunner for realtime nodes, have added that

dimension names should be case insensitive. If this is not the case, can you provide more details of the problem you are encountering?
This has been fixed in 0.6.72
I can't automatically merge this request.

These mvn central is coming from artifact descriptors for dependencies collection,
aether provides support to disable that by configuring RepositorySystemSession to ignoreArtifactDescriptorRepositories..

also, I'm not sure that the core /datasources/[dataSourceName] should return so much info about the segments, as that info is available in /datasources/[dataSourceName]/segments.  I think /datasources/[dataSourceName] should return higher-level summary info, maybe like:

```
name: dataSourceName
tiers: [ {tierName, segmentCount, size}, ... ]
segments: {count, size, minTime, maxTime} 
properties: {}
```
created - https://github.com/tesla/tesla-aether/issues/5
actually I don't think this will do what we want

Hi sixtus, let me try and understand the issue a bit more. So you have two rt nodes, one with linear shard spec 1 and the other with linear shard spec 2. Are these same linear shards replicated across multiple nodes? It seems like you are saying the are. So the problem you are having is that the broker seems to be adding the results for linear shard spec 1 and the copy? If this is the case, perhaps we should chat about the numbered shard spec, which is what we use in production. If this is not the case, perhaps you can help me understand the problem a bit more.
documentation changes on the way.

ok, so I got two kafka topics:

"big" - which is just massive (95% of all events)
"important" - which contains the really important events (the important 5%)

they are supposed to go into the same data source. So I use linear sharding to have a setup like this:
feed: "big" / partition:1 / kafka-group: big-read
feed: "big" / partition:2 / kafka-group: big-read
...
feed: "big" / partition:7 / kafka-group: big-read
feed: "important" / partition: 100 / kafka-group: important-ha-1
feed: "important" / partition: 100 / kafka-group: important-ha-2

which makes perfect sense to me. I really need that many rts for "big", and I really don't want "important" to ever go down.

However, the broker gets confused and includes both rts serving partition 100. Once the segments reach historical nodes, all is good.

Tranquility tests don't pass with this branch because it calls isPostgreSQL(...) in createConfigTable by way of lifecycle.start(), due to the hook installed by JacksonConfigManager. That table creation business never worked in tranquility's tests, but the tables were never accessed and DbConnector suppresses exceptions while creating them, so it worked out okay.

What needs to be done to make the ConfigManager implementation pluggable? I think overall that'd be a lot less janky than trying to just avoid all the exceptions caused by not having a database...
oops

this pr as a whoel is pretty ugly and is a quick and dirty fix to remove the check for postgres somewhere later in the execution flow, if we want the correct soln of making config manager pluggable, will require a bit more work
let's go with the correct soln, tranq tests may be broken for a little while longer

The problem with numbered shard is that they all must be available or the segment is not up, right?

That's an issue, once a feed gets bigger than a single cpu can take.
Seems ok, can't close as not owner
Closing this issue for now based on feedback from sixtus.
Which class does the request fan out, the I see into a PR to get this fixed. Tnx

Hi Frank, I think we all agree that the database stuff should be more pluggable.

The specific issue around Druid trying to connect to the DB has been addressed in this pull request https://github.com/metamx/druid/commit/bc4bc277f2709ab10c119648e71cc342dad1e27b . Do you mind trying out master, and see if this fixes your problem?

You mention other storage options, which ones were you thinking about specifically?

I can see how local storage could be useful. How about sharing what you did and contributing your code back to the community?

@xvrl Thank you for reply. @fjy also point this out in email thread. You guys are awesome.

The other storage options I talked about is something other than sql, say, a key-value storage like S3, hbase, etc.

We are using something similar to S3 internally which serves for general purpose key-value storage and has a whole team to support/maintain, which would be more reliable than using mysql hot/cold solution IMHO.

I definitely would like to try to contribute back when I got chance to do so.
BTW, I tried 0.6.76 and it fixes my problem.

Great to hear the issue is fixed for you.

For us the main reason to use MySQL was really just convenience. We could have used any other database, but given our environment, that was the simplest way to store metadata.

As far as key-value stores are concerned, I don't think S3 would work very well as metadata storage for the coordinator, because of eventual consistency issues. The metadata store needs to have some transactional guarantees.
Agreed S3 eventual consistency issue is a problem. We deliberately avoided this issue by talking to only one colocation instead of global vip.
I think as we move out caching to the historical nodes, this feature may be better implemented at the broker level, but a great suggestion nonetheless.
This was fixed.
This has been fixed.

@cheddar says: RealtimeManager is the culprit, it builds a Map<String, FireChief> where String is the data source name that should be data source + shard Then, on query, it needs to look at what shards are available and what was asked for in the query and route accordingly

Hi Hagen, a few more questions to narrow down the problem.

Do you always see this behavior?
Do you only see this querying for multiple segments?
Do you see this for querying a single segment?
Do you see this for querying segments that are paritioned?
I've reproduced this problem and will look into it more.

So we're fairly certain that the difference between groupBy and timeseries is a result of floating point rounding errors when merging groupBy results. This is just a result of how Druid handles metrics as floats during groupBy merges. The difference between timeseries and camus though is worth investigating, because that should be the same.

a count metric is an integer, how can that possible cause an issue if handled as a float. and why is it a float to begin with?

Anyhow, great to see some of it reproducable. How to best continue? Needs this fixed :)
Thanks for the docs fix!

For compute nodes returning results to bard we probably don't even need to finalize at all and let bard do it. 

> On Apr 7, 2014, at 14:59, nishantmonu51 notifications@github.com wrote:
> 
> This PR improves performance by only calculating the postAggregations once, rather then calculating N times during merge process when N results are being merged into single result.
> 
> Calculate postAggregations only after all the results are merged while finalizing results. 
> For topN in case sorting is done on a post aggregated value only that is calculated before finalization

Ah, sorry, I expected it to be part of the PR. I think it's good practice not to fix in master directly since it makes it easier to track things and compile change logs on for releases

as an alternative to hashed partition, we can use dimension based partition in which the partitions are done based on a single dimension, the benefits of using hash based partition over single dimension partitions are that its faster and gives better distribution of data in the segments.

Hi @prepor, groupBy currently does not support complex metrics.
topN and timeseries should return the same result though, can you provide more details on how the data was indexed, and what you the topN output looks like?

The 'hyperUniqueCardinality' post-aggregator is required to convert the sketch into a number.
By default, aggregations get converted automatically, but if you wanted to use the sketch inside of a postAggregation, you would have to convert it to a number explicitly first. This is to allow other postAggregators to work directly on the sketch as opposed to just on the number.

This saw a slight update in that there are now load/drop forever rules. As for default drop rules at the end of a rule list, there are use cases where no rule can be applied to a segment because of misconfiguration, and I think it may be a big dangerous to just drop the segment in such cases.
Hey guys, is there still a problem or can I resolve it?
I _thought_ at some point @cheddar made some workarounds for groupBy to support hyerloglog. Need to double check with him about this.
It seems it can be avoided by configuration. sum of brokers' http connections vs. historical's threads. broker locks up if larger.
